Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On December 12, 1904, 
Chief Lontulu laid 110 twigs in front of a foreign commission. Every twig represented a person 
in his village who died because of King Leopold’s horrific regime
in the Congo— all in the name of rubber. Chief Lontulu separated the twigs 
into four piles: tribal nobles, men, women, and children— then proceeded
to name the dead of one-by-one. His testimony joined hundreds of others
to help bring an end to one of the greatest atrocities 
in history. Beginning in the late 1800s, European countries participated in the
so-called “Scramble for Africa.” They colonized 90% of the continent, exploiting African resources 
and enriching their countries. Belgium had recently become
an independent kingdom. Its ruler, Leopold II, 
wanted to acquire what he called “a slice of this magnificent 
African cake.” Meanwhile, he read colonial explorer 
Henry Morton Stanley’s reports about traveling through Africa. Stanley emphasized 
the Congo basin’s majesty. So, in 1879, Leopold contracted him
to return to the Congo. There, Stanley deceived leaders 
into signing some 450 treaties allowing for land use. Leopold persuaded the US and European
powers to grant him ownership of the Congo, pledging to protect free trade 
in the region. And on May 29, 1885, a territory more than
80 times the size of Belgium and home to 20 million people was declared
his own private colony— by no one it actually belonged to. Leopold lost no time consolidating power 
in what he called the Congo Free State. He claimed land, raised an army, and forced many Congolese men
to complete unpaid labor. Things got even worse when, in 1887, a Scottish inventor redeveloped
the pneumatic tire, creating a massive international
market for rubber. The Congo had one of the world’s
largest supplies. Leopold seized the opportunity, requiring villages to meet 
ever-greater rubber quotas. Congolese men had to harvest
the material from wild vines. As supplies drained, they walked for days
to gather enough. Leopold’s army entered villages and held 
women and children hostage until the impossible quota was met. Soldiers sexually violated women 
and deprived children of food and water. Congolese people rebelled— they refused to cooperate, 
fought Leopold’s soldiers, hid in the forests, 
and destroyed rubber vines. Leopold’s army responded to resistance 
or failure to meet quotas with unflinching torture and executions. Because guns and ammunition
were expensive, officers ordered soldiers to prove they 
used their bullets in the line of duty by removing a hand from anyone 
they killed. However, many soldiers hunted 
using their guns. To avoid harsh penalties and account 
for lost bullets, they cut off living people’s hands. They also used this practice
as punishment. If rubber quotas weren’t met, soldiers would sever people’s hands
and bring them to their commanders instead of rubber. The regime dramatically upended
daily life and agriculture, causing widespread starvation and disease. Meanwhile, King Leopold built monuments 
and private estates with the wealth he extracted. Soon, people brought international
attention to the horrific abuses of Leopold’s Congo Free State. In 1890, American journalist 
George Washington Williams accused King Leopold of “deceit, fraud, 
robberies, arson, murder, slave-raiding,
and [a] general policy of cruelty.” In 1903, Diplomat Roger Casement 
wrote a report that corroborated the nature and scale of the atrocities. It was published the following year. In response, Leopold appointed his own 
commission to investigate the accusations. They heard numerous witness statements 
in the Congo— Chief Lontulu’s included. The report only confirmed the worst. Facing pressure, Leopold relinquished 
control of the Congo to the Belgian government in 1908. But this did not mean justice. The Belgian state awarded Leopold
50 million francs “in testimony for his great sacrifice 
in favor of the Congo.” He died the following year. Crowds booed his funeral procession. For more than 50 years following,
the Congo remained a Belgian colony, until declaring independence in 1960. That year, the Congo elected its first
prime minister, Patrice Lumumba. But months later, he was unseated 
in a US and Belgium backed coup. In early 1961, Lumumba was assassinated 
under Belgian supervision. The coup launched the country 
into a decades-long dictatorship. Around 10 million Congolese people 
are thought to have died during Leopold’s occupation and looting 
of the Congo. Despite this devastation, calls 
for reparations have gone unanswered. To this day, throughout Belgium can be 
found the monuments King Leopold built on a foundation of inconceivable cruelty.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following natural resources was primarily exploited by King Leopold’s colonization of the Congo?
Options: A. Gold, B. Petroleum, C. Rubber, D. Agricultural products
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who laid 110 twigs in front of a foreign commission to represent the people in his village who died due to King Leopold's regime? Options: A. King Leopold, B. Chief Lontulu, C. Henry Morton Stanley, D. George Washington Williams Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the main reason behind the increased demand for rubber from the Congo in 1887? Options: A. The discovery of new rubber plantations, B. The redevelopment of the pneumatic tire, C. The expansion of the Congo Free State, D. The rise of the automobile industry Correct Option: B
Question 3: How did Leopold's army respond to resistance or failure to meet rubber quotas in the Congo? Options: A. By providing additional support and resources, B. By imposing harsh penalties and executions, C. By offering incentives and rewards, D. By ignoring the issue Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the outcome of King Leopold's investigation into the accusations of atrocities in the Congo? Options: A. The report found no evidence of wrongdoing, B. The report confirmed the worst atrocities, C. The report was inconclusive, D. The report was never published Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the significance of the 450 treaties signed by Henry Morton Stanley with Congolese leaders? Options: A. They granted the Congolese people independence, B. They allowed for the establishment of trade relationships, C. They gave Leopold ownership of the Congo, D. They deceived leaders into allowing land use Correct Option: D
Question 6: If you were a historian analyzing the impact of King Leopold's regime on the Congo, what would be a crucial factor to consider? Options: A. The economic benefits of colonialism, B. The role of international diplomacy in ending the atrocities, C. The long-term effects of the regime on the Congolese people and their culture, D. The technological advancements of the time Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did the international community respond to the revelations of atrocities in the Congo? Options: A. They immediately intervened to stop the atrocities, B. They provided economic support to King Leopold, C. They published reports and brought attention to the issue, D. They ignored the situation Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the outcome of the Belgian government taking control of the Congo from King Leopold in 1908? Options: A. The Congo gained independence, B. King Leopold was held accountable for his actions, C. The Belgian government awarded Leopold 50 million francs, D. The Congo became a French colony Correct Option: C
Question 9: If you were to evaluate the legacy of King Leopold's regime in the Congo, what would be a key consideration? Options: A. The economic benefits of colonialism, B. The cultural exchange between Belgium and the Congo, C. The devastating impact on the Congolese people and their human rights, D. The technological advancements of the time Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the ongoing issue related to King Leopold's regime in the Congo that remains unresolved? Options: A. The restoration of historical monuments, B. The recognition of the Congo's independence, C. The calls for reparations for the Congolese people, D. The rehabilitation of King Leopold's image Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although Question 2 does not directly ask about the primary natural resource exploited by King Leopold's colonization of the Congo, it does relate to the increased demand for rubber from the Congo in 1887. The correct option in Question 2 (B. The redevelopment of the pneumatic tire) implies that rubber was a crucial resource, linking it to the ground truth MCQ's focus on the primary exploited resource (rubber). 

However, it is essential to note that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. If more generated MCQs were provided or created with a focus on the natural resources exploited during King Leopold's colonization, a more similar match might be found.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On December 12, 1904, 
Chief Lontulu laid 110 twigs in front of a foreign commission. Every twig represented a person 
in his village who died because of King Leopold’s horrific regime
in the Congo— all in the name of rubber. Chief Lontulu separated the twigs 
into four piles: tribal nobles, men, women, and children— then proceeded
to name the dead of one-by-one. His testimony joined hundreds of others
to help bring an end to one of the greatest atrocities 
in history. Beginning in the late 1800s, European countries participated in the
so-called “Scramble for Africa.” They colonized 90% of the continent, exploiting African resources 
and enriching their countries. Belgium had recently become
an independent kingdom. Its ruler, Leopold II, 
wanted to acquire what he called “a slice of this magnificent 
African cake.” Meanwhile, he read colonial explorer 
Henry Morton Stanley’s reports about traveling through Africa. Stanley emphasized 
the Congo basin’s majesty. So, in 1879, Leopold contracted him
to return to the Congo. There, Stanley deceived leaders 
into signing some 450 treaties allowing for land use. Leopold persuaded the US and European
powers to grant him ownership of the Congo, pledging to protect free trade 
in the region. And on May 29, 1885, a territory more than
80 times the size of Belgium and home to 20 million people was declared
his own private colony— by no one it actually belonged to. Leopold lost no time consolidating power 
in what he called the Congo Free State. He claimed land, raised an army, and forced many Congolese men
to complete unpaid labor. Things got even worse when, in 1887, a Scottish inventor redeveloped
the pneumatic tire, creating a massive international
market for rubber. The Congo had one of the world’s
largest supplies. Leopold seized the opportunity, requiring villages to meet 
ever-greater rubber quotas. Congolese men had to harvest
the material from wild vines. As supplies drained, they walked for days
to gather enough. Leopold’s army entered villages and held 
women and children hostage until the impossible quota was met. Soldiers sexually violated women 
and deprived children of food and water. Congolese people rebelled— they refused to cooperate, 
fought Leopold’s soldiers, hid in the forests, 
and destroyed rubber vines. Leopold’s army responded to resistance 
or failure to meet quotas with unflinching torture and executions. Because guns and ammunition
were expensive, officers ordered soldiers to prove they 
used their bullets in the line of duty by removing a hand from anyone 
they killed. However, many soldiers hunted 
using their guns. To avoid harsh penalties and account 
for lost bullets, they cut off living people’s hands. They also used this practice
as punishment. If rubber quotas weren’t met, soldiers would sever people’s hands
and bring them to their commanders instead of rubber. The regime dramatically upended
daily life and agriculture, causing widespread starvation and disease. Meanwhile, King Leopold built monuments 
and private estates with the wealth he extracted. Soon, people brought international
attention to the horrific abuses of Leopold’s Congo Free State. In 1890, American journalist 
George Washington Williams accused King Leopold of “deceit, fraud, 
robberies, arson, murder, slave-raiding,
and [a] general policy of cruelty.” In 1903, Diplomat Roger Casement 
wrote a report that corroborated the nature and scale of the atrocities. It was published the following year. In response, Leopold appointed his own 
commission to investigate the accusations. They heard numerous witness statements 
in the Congo— Chief Lontulu’s included. The report only confirmed the worst. Facing pressure, Leopold relinquished 
control of the Congo to the Belgian government in 1908. But this did not mean justice. The Belgian state awarded Leopold
50 million francs “in testimony for his great sacrifice 
in favor of the Congo.” He died the following year. Crowds booed his funeral procession. For more than 50 years following,
the Congo remained a Belgian colony, until declaring independence in 1960. That year, the Congo elected its first
prime minister, Patrice Lumumba. But months later, he was unseated 
in a US and Belgium backed coup. In early 1961, Lumumba was assassinated 
under Belgian supervision. The coup launched the country 
into a decades-long dictatorship. Around 10 million Congolese people 
are thought to have died during Leopold’s occupation and looting 
of the Congo. Despite this devastation, calls 
for reparations have gone unanswered. To this day, throughout Belgium can be 
found the monuments King Leopold built on a foundation of inconceivable cruelty.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following figures accused King Leopold of “deceit, fraud, robberies, arson, murder, slave-raiding, and [a] general policy of cruelty”?
Options: A. Roger Casement, B. Mark Twain, C. George Washington Williams, D. William Henry Sheppard
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who laid 110 twigs in front of a foreign commission to represent the people in his village who died due to King Leopold's regime? Options: A. King Leopold, B. Chief Lontulu, C. Henry Morton Stanley, D. George Washington Williams Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the main reason behind the increased demand for rubber from the Congo in 1887? Options: A. The discovery of new rubber plantations, B. The redevelopment of the pneumatic tire, C. The expansion of the Congo Free State, D. The rise of the automobile industry Correct Option: B
Question 3: How did Leopold's army respond to resistance or failure to meet rubber quotas in the Congo? Options: A. By providing additional support and resources, B. By imposing harsh penalties and executions, C. By offering incentives and rewards, D. By ignoring the issue Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the outcome of King Leopold's investigation into the accusations of atrocities in the Congo? Options: A. The report found no evidence of wrongdoing, B. The report confirmed the worst atrocities, C. The report was inconclusive, D. The report was never published Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the significance of the 450 treaties signed by Henry Morton Stanley with Congolese leaders? Options: A. They granted the Congolese people independence, B. They allowed for the establishment of trade relationships, C. They gave Leopold ownership of the Congo, D. They deceived leaders into allowing land use Correct Option: D
Question 6: If you were a historian analyzing the impact of King Leopold's regime on the Congo, what would be a crucial factor to consider? Options: A. The economic benefits of colonialism, B. The role of international diplomacy in ending the atrocities, C. The long-term effects of the regime on the Congolese people and their culture, D. The technological advancements of the time Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did the international community respond to the revelations of atrocities in the Congo? Options: A. They immediately intervened to stop the atrocities, B. They provided economic support to King Leopold, C. They published reports and brought attention to the issue, D. They ignored the situation Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the outcome of the Belgian government taking control of the Congo from King Leopold in 1908? Options: A. The Congo gained independence, B. King Leopold was held accountable for his actions, C. The Belgian government awarded Leopold 50 million francs, D. The Congo became a French colony Correct Option: C
Question 9: If you were to evaluate the legacy of King Leopold's regime in the Congo, what would be a key consideration? Options: A. The economic benefits of colonialism, B. The cultural exchange between Belgium and the Congo, C. The devastating impact on the Congolese people and their human rights, D. The technological advancements of the time Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the ongoing issue related to King Leopold's regime in the Congo that remains unresolved? Options: A. The restoration of historical monuments, B. The recognition of the Congo's independence, C. The calls for reparations for the Congolese people, D. The rehabilitation of King Leopold's image Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the content and intent, I would say that Question 7: "How did the international community respond to the revelations of atrocities in the Congo?" is the closest match.

Although the question and options are not identical, Question 7 does relate to the international response to King Leopold's regime, which is the context in which George Washington Williams accused King Leopold of various atrocities.

A more suitable match would be a generated MCQ that directly asks about who accused King Leopold of the specified atrocities, but such a question is not present among the generated MCQs.

Therefore, I will not provide an index of a matching generated MCQ. Instead, I suggest creating a new generated MCQ that directly matches the ground truth MCQ. 

Here is an example of a new generated MCQ that matches the ground truth MCQ:

Question: Who accused King Leopold of “deceit, fraud, robberies, arson, murder, slave-raiding, and [a] general policy of cruelty”?
Options: A. Roger Casement, B. Mark Twain, C. George Washington Williams, D. William Henry Sheppard
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On December 12, 1904, 
Chief Lontulu laid 110 twigs in front of a foreign commission. Every twig represented a person 
in his village who died because of King Leopold’s horrific regime
in the Congo— all in the name of rubber. Chief Lontulu separated the twigs 
into four piles: tribal nobles, men, women, and children— then proceeded
to name the dead of one-by-one. His testimony joined hundreds of others
to help bring an end to one of the greatest atrocities 
in history. Beginning in the late 1800s, European countries participated in the
so-called “Scramble for Africa.” They colonized 90% of the continent, exploiting African resources 
and enriching their countries. Belgium had recently become
an independent kingdom. Its ruler, Leopold II, 
wanted to acquire what he called “a slice of this magnificent 
African cake.” Meanwhile, he read colonial explorer 
Henry Morton Stanley’s reports about traveling through Africa. Stanley emphasized 
the Congo basin’s majesty. So, in 1879, Leopold contracted him
to return to the Congo. There, Stanley deceived leaders 
into signing some 450 treaties allowing for land use. Leopold persuaded the US and European
powers to grant him ownership of the Congo, pledging to protect free trade 
in the region. And on May 29, 1885, a territory more than
80 times the size of Belgium and home to 20 million people was declared
his own private colony— by no one it actually belonged to. Leopold lost no time consolidating power 
in what he called the Congo Free State. He claimed land, raised an army, and forced many Congolese men
to complete unpaid labor. Things got even worse when, in 1887, a Scottish inventor redeveloped
the pneumatic tire, creating a massive international
market for rubber. The Congo had one of the world’s
largest supplies. Leopold seized the opportunity, requiring villages to meet 
ever-greater rubber quotas. Congolese men had to harvest
the material from wild vines. As supplies drained, they walked for days
to gather enough. Leopold’s army entered villages and held 
women and children hostage until the impossible quota was met. Soldiers sexually violated women 
and deprived children of food and water. Congolese people rebelled— they refused to cooperate, 
fought Leopold’s soldiers, hid in the forests, 
and destroyed rubber vines. Leopold’s army responded to resistance 
or failure to meet quotas with unflinching torture and executions. Because guns and ammunition
were expensive, officers ordered soldiers to prove they 
used their bullets in the line of duty by removing a hand from anyone 
they killed. However, many soldiers hunted 
using their guns. To avoid harsh penalties and account 
for lost bullets, they cut off living people’s hands. They also used this practice
as punishment. If rubber quotas weren’t met, soldiers would sever people’s hands
and bring them to their commanders instead of rubber. The regime dramatically upended
daily life and agriculture, causing widespread starvation and disease. Meanwhile, King Leopold built monuments 
and private estates with the wealth he extracted. Soon, people brought international
attention to the horrific abuses of Leopold’s Congo Free State. In 1890, American journalist 
George Washington Williams accused King Leopold of “deceit, fraud, 
robberies, arson, murder, slave-raiding,
and [a] general policy of cruelty.” In 1903, Diplomat Roger Casement 
wrote a report that corroborated the nature and scale of the atrocities. It was published the following year. In response, Leopold appointed his own 
commission to investigate the accusations. They heard numerous witness statements 
in the Congo— Chief Lontulu’s included. The report only confirmed the worst. Facing pressure, Leopold relinquished 
control of the Congo to the Belgian government in 1908. But this did not mean justice. The Belgian state awarded Leopold
50 million francs “in testimony for his great sacrifice 
in favor of the Congo.” He died the following year. Crowds booed his funeral procession. For more than 50 years following,
the Congo remained a Belgian colony, until declaring independence in 1960. That year, the Congo elected its first
prime minister, Patrice Lumumba. But months later, he was unseated 
in a US and Belgium backed coup. In early 1961, Lumumba was assassinated 
under Belgian supervision. The coup launched the country 
into a decades-long dictatorship. Around 10 million Congolese people 
are thought to have died during Leopold’s occupation and looting 
of the Congo. Despite this devastation, calls 
for reparations have gone unanswered. To this day, throughout Belgium can be 
found the monuments King Leopold built on a foundation of inconceivable cruelty.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In what year did the Congo declare independence?
Options: A. 1988, B. 1957, C. 1945, D. 1960
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who laid 110 twigs in front of a foreign commission to represent the people in his village who died due to King Leopold's regime? Options: A. King Leopold, B. Chief Lontulu, C. Henry Morton Stanley, D. George Washington Williams Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the main reason behind the increased demand for rubber from the Congo in 1887? Options: A. The discovery of new rubber plantations, B. The redevelopment of the pneumatic tire, C. The expansion of the Congo Free State, D. The rise of the automobile industry Correct Option: B
Question 3: How did Leopold's army respond to resistance or failure to meet rubber quotas in the Congo? Options: A. By providing additional support and resources, B. By imposing harsh penalties and executions, C. By offering incentives and rewards, D. By ignoring the issue Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the outcome of King Leopold's investigation into the accusations of atrocities in the Congo? Options: A. The report found no evidence of wrongdoing, B. The report confirmed the worst atrocities, C. The report was inconclusive, D. The report was never published Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the significance of the 450 treaties signed by Henry Morton Stanley with Congolese leaders? Options: A. They granted the Congolese people independence, B. They allowed for the establishment of trade relationships, C. They gave Leopold ownership of the Congo, D. They deceived leaders into allowing land use Correct Option: D
Question 6: If you were a historian analyzing the impact of King Leopold's regime on the Congo, what would be a crucial factor to consider? Options: A. The economic benefits of colonialism, B. The role of international diplomacy in ending the atrocities, C. The long-term effects of the regime on the Congolese people and their culture, D. The technological advancements of the time Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did the international community respond to the revelations of atrocities in the Congo? Options: A. They immediately intervened to stop the atrocities, B. They provided economic support to King Leopold, C. They published reports and brought attention to the issue, D. They ignored the situation Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the outcome of the Belgian government taking control of the Congo from King Leopold in 1908? Options: A. The Congo gained independence, B. King Leopold was held accountable for his actions, C. The Belgian government awarded Leopold 50 million francs, D. The Congo became a French colony Correct Option: C
Question 9: If you were to evaluate the legacy of King Leopold's regime in the Congo, what would be a key consideration? Options: A. The economic benefits of colonialism, B. The cultural exchange between Belgium and the Congo, C. The devastating impact on the Congolese people and their human rights, D. The technological advancements of the time Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the ongoing issue related to King Leopold's regime in the Congo that remains unresolved? Options: A. The restoration of historical monuments, B. The recognition of the Congo's independence, C. The calls for reparations for the Congolese people, D. The rehabilitation of King Leopold's image Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the year the Congo declared independence. While none of the generated MCQs ask this exact question, Question 8 mentions the outcome of the Belgian government taking control of the Congo from King Leopold in 1908, which is related to the Congo's independence.

However, a more relevant generated MCQ would be one that directly addresses the Congo's independence. Unfortunately, such a question is not present among the generated MCQs.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the available options, I would say that none of the generated MCQs are a good match for the ground truth MCQ. However, if I had to pick one, I would say Question 8 is the closest, but it's still not a good match.

Index: 8 (Please note that this is not a direct match, and the generated MCQs do not provide a good match for the ground truth MCQ.)

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On December 12, 1904, 
Chief Lontulu laid 110 twigs in front of a foreign commission. Every twig represented a person 
in his village who died because of King Leopold’s horrific regime
in the Congo— all in the name of rubber. Chief Lontulu separated the twigs 
into four piles: tribal nobles, men, women, and children— then proceeded
to name the dead of one-by-one. His testimony joined hundreds of others
to help bring an end to one of the greatest atrocities 
in history. Beginning in the late 1800s, European countries participated in the
so-called “Scramble for Africa.” They colonized 90% of the continent, exploiting African resources 
and enriching their countries. Belgium had recently become
an independent kingdom. Its ruler, Leopold II, 
wanted to acquire what he called “a slice of this magnificent 
African cake.” Meanwhile, he read colonial explorer 
Henry Morton Stanley’s reports about traveling through Africa. Stanley emphasized 
the Congo basin’s majesty. So, in 1879, Leopold contracted him
to return to the Congo. There, Stanley deceived leaders 
into signing some 450 treaties allowing for land use. Leopold persuaded the US and European
powers to grant him ownership of the Congo, pledging to protect free trade 
in the region. And on May 29, 1885, a territory more than
80 times the size of Belgium and home to 20 million people was declared
his own private colony— by no one it actually belonged to. Leopold lost no time consolidating power 
in what he called the Congo Free State. He claimed land, raised an army, and forced many Congolese men
to complete unpaid labor. Things got even worse when, in 1887, a Scottish inventor redeveloped
the pneumatic tire, creating a massive international
market for rubber. The Congo had one of the world’s
largest supplies. Leopold seized the opportunity, requiring villages to meet 
ever-greater rubber quotas. Congolese men had to harvest
the material from wild vines. As supplies drained, they walked for days
to gather enough. Leopold’s army entered villages and held 
women and children hostage until the impossible quota was met. Soldiers sexually violated women 
and deprived children of food and water. Congolese people rebelled— they refused to cooperate, 
fought Leopold’s soldiers, hid in the forests, 
and destroyed rubber vines. Leopold’s army responded to resistance 
or failure to meet quotas with unflinching torture and executions. Because guns and ammunition
were expensive, officers ordered soldiers to prove they 
used their bullets in the line of duty by removing a hand from anyone 
they killed. However, many soldiers hunted 
using their guns. To avoid harsh penalties and account 
for lost bullets, they cut off living people’s hands. They also used this practice
as punishment. If rubber quotas weren’t met, soldiers would sever people’s hands
and bring them to their commanders instead of rubber. The regime dramatically upended
daily life and agriculture, causing widespread starvation and disease. Meanwhile, King Leopold built monuments 
and private estates with the wealth he extracted. Soon, people brought international
attention to the horrific abuses of Leopold’s Congo Free State. In 1890, American journalist 
George Washington Williams accused King Leopold of “deceit, fraud, 
robberies, arson, murder, slave-raiding,
and [a] general policy of cruelty.” In 1903, Diplomat Roger Casement 
wrote a report that corroborated the nature and scale of the atrocities. It was published the following year. In response, Leopold appointed his own 
commission to investigate the accusations. They heard numerous witness statements 
in the Congo— Chief Lontulu’s included. The report only confirmed the worst. Facing pressure, Leopold relinquished 
control of the Congo to the Belgian government in 1908. But this did not mean justice. The Belgian state awarded Leopold
50 million francs “in testimony for his great sacrifice 
in favor of the Congo.” He died the following year. Crowds booed his funeral procession. For more than 50 years following,
the Congo remained a Belgian colony, until declaring independence in 1960. That year, the Congo elected its first
prime minister, Patrice Lumumba. But months later, he was unseated 
in a US and Belgium backed coup. In early 1961, Lumumba was assassinated 
under Belgian supervision. The coup launched the country 
into a decades-long dictatorship. Around 10 million Congolese people 
are thought to have died during Leopold’s occupation and looting 
of the Congo. Despite this devastation, calls 
for reparations have gone unanswered. To this day, throughout Belgium can be 
found the monuments King Leopold built on a foundation of inconceivable cruelty.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: ___ was the (Democratic Republic of the Congo) République du Congo’s first elected prime minister
Options: A. Étienne Tshisekedi, B. Patrice Lumumba, C. Roger Casement, D. Évariste Kimba
Correct Option: B

in his village who died because of King Leopold’s horrific regime
in the Congo— all in the name of rubber. Chief Lontulu separated the twigs 
into four piles: tribal nobles, men, women, and children— then proceeded
to name the dead of one-by-one. His testimony joined hundreds of others
to help bring an end to one of the greatest atrocities 
in history. Beginning in the late 1800s, European countries participated in the
so-called “Scramble for Africa.” They colonized 90% of the continent, exploiting African resources 
and enriching their countries. Belgium had recently become
an independent kingdom. Its ruler, Leopold II, 
wanted to acquire what he called “a slice of this magnificent 
African cake.” Meanwhile, he read colonial explorer 
Henry Morton Stanley’s reports about traveling through Africa. Stanley emphasized 
the Congo basin’s majesty. So, in 1879, Leopold contracted him
to return to the Congo. There, Stanley deceived leaders 
into signing some 450 treaties allowing for land use. Leopold persuaded the US and European

market for rubber. The Congo had one of the world’s
largest supplies. Leopold seized the opportunity, requiring villages to meet 
ever-greater rubber quotas. Congolese men had to harvest
the material from wild vines. As supplies drained, they walked for days
to gather enough. Leopold’s army entered villages and held 
women and children hostage until the impossible quota was met. Soldiers sexually violated women 
and deprived children of food and water. Congolese people rebelled— they refused to cooperate, 
fought Leopold’s soldiers, hid in the forests, 
and destroyed rubber vines. Leopold’s army responded to resistance 
or failure to meet quotas with unflinching torture and executions. Because guns and ammunition
were expensive, officers ordered soldiers to prove they 
used their bullets in the line of duty by removing a hand from anyone 
they killed. However, many soldiers hunted 
using their guns. To avoid harsh penalties and account 
for lost bullets, they cut off living people’s hands. They also used this practice
as punishment. If rubber quotas weren’t met, soldiers would sever people’s hands
and bring them to their commanders instead of rubber. The regime dramatically upended

and private estates with the wealth he extracted. Soon, people brought international

robberies, arson, murder, slave-raiding,
and [a] general policy of cruelty.” In 1903, Diplomat Roger Casement

in favor of the Congo.” He died the following year. Crowds booed his funeral procession. For more than 50 years following,

in a US and Belgium backed coup. In early 1961, Lumumba was assassinated 
under Belgian supervision. The coup launched the country 
into a decades-long dictatorship. Around 10 million Congolese people 
are thought to have died during Leopold’s occupation and looting 
of the Congo. Despite this devastation, calls 
for reparations have gone unanswered. To this day, throughout Belgium can be 
found the monuments King Leopold built on a foundation of inconceivable cruelty.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: True or False: King Leopold was awarded 50 million francs for his colonial reign in the Congo
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In early 1828, Sojourner Truth approached
the Grand Jury of Kingston, New York. She had no experience 
with the legal system, no money, and no power 
in the eyes of the court. Ignoring the jury’s scorn, Truth said she was there to fight for
custody of her five-year-old son Peter, who’d been illegally sold 
to an enslaver in Alabama. As the trial played out 
over the next several months, Truth raised funds, 
strategized with lawyers, and held her faith. Finally in the spring of 1828, 
Peter was returned to her care— but Truth’s work was far from over. She would dedicate 
the rest of her life to pursuing justice and spiritual understanding. Truth was born into slavery 
as Isabella Baumfree in the late 18th century
in Ulster County, New York. Although New York state had announced 
the abolition of slavery in 1799, the emancipation act was gradual. Those who were currently enslaved were forced to serve a period of 
indentured servitude until their mid-20s. Throughout this period, 
enslavers repeatedly sold Baumfree, tearing her from her loved ones. Often, she was explicitly prevented 
from pursuing new relationships. Eventually, she married an enslaved man 
named Thomas, with whom she had three children. She was desperate to keep 
her new family together— but the slow progress of abolition 
threatened this hope. Baumfree’s enslaver, John Dumont, 
had promised to free her by 1826. When he failed to keep his word, 
Baumfree fled for her safety. During the escape, she was only able 
to rescue her youngest daughter Sophia, while her other children 
remained in bondage. It would be two years before 
she regained custody of Peter. After that, she would wait 
another two years before she saw any of her other children. During this time, 
Baumfree found solace in her faith and became increasingly dedicated 
to religious reflection. After settling in Kingston, New York, she joined a Methodist community 
that shared her political views. She continued her practice of speaking 
aloud to God in private, and one night, her evening prayers
took on even more sacred significance. Baumfree claimed to hear the voice 
of God, telling her to leave Kingston, and share her holy message with others. Though she never learned to read or write, Baumfree became known 
as an electrifying orator, whose speeches drew on 
Biblical references, spiritual ideals, 
and her experience of slavery. Her sermons denounced the oppression 
of African Americans and women in general, and became prominent in campaigns 
for both abolition and women’s rights. In 1843, she renamed herself 
Sojourner Truth and embarked on a legendary 
speaking tour. Truth saw her journey 
as a mission from God. Her faith often led her 
to the nation’s most hostile regions, where she spoke to bigoted audiences 
as the only Black woman in the crowd. Truth was confident God would protect her, but some crowds responded 
to her bravery with violence. During one of her sermons, a mob of white men threatened to set 
fire to the tent where she was speaking. In her memoir, Truth recalled steeling 
herself to confront them: “Have I not faith enough to go out 
and quell that mob… I felt as if I had three hearts! And that they were so large, 
my body could hardly hold them!” She placated the men with song and prayer,
until they had no desire to harm her. Truth’s speeches impacted thousands of
people in communities across the nation, but her activism went far beyond
public speaking. During the Civil War, she became involved
with the Union Army, recruiting soldiers and organizing 
supplies for Black troops. Her work was so well regarded that 
she was invited to meet President Lincoln. She took the occasion to argue 
that all formerly enslaved people should be granted land by the government. Truth continued to travel 
and speak well into her 80s. Until her death in 1883, 
she remained an outspoken critic who fought for her right to be heard 
in a hostile world. As Truth once said, “I feel safe even
in the midst of my enemies; for the truth is powerful 
and will prevail."

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was Sojourner Truth’s name at birth?
Options: A. Sally Turner, B. Isabella Baumfree, C. Harriet Douglass, D. Isabel Lewis
Correct Option: B

Question 2: What was the main reason Sojourner Truth's enslaver, John Dumont, failed to keep his promise to free her by 1826? Options: A. He was not legally required to free her, B. He changed his mind about abolition, C. The transcript does not specify a reason, D. He was forced to keep her due to economic reasons Correct Option: C
Question 3: Imagine you are a lawyer helping Sojourner Truth in her case to regain custody of her son Peter. What would be a crucial piece of evidence to present to the court? Options: A. Proof of Truth's financial stability, B. Testimony from Peter's enslaver in Alabama, C. Documentation of Peter's illegal sale to the enslaver in Alabama, D. Character witnesses for Truth's parenting abilities Correct Option: C
Question 4: How did Sojourner Truth's experiences with slavery and abolition influence her later work as an orator and activist? Options: A. They led her to focus solely on women's rights, B. They caused her to become disillusioned with the abolition movement, C. They shaped her speeches and sermons, which denounced oppression and advocated for abolition and women's rights, D. They had no impact on her later work Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the significance of Sojourner Truth's decision to rename herself in 1843? Options: A. It marked her conversion to a new religion, B. It signaled her transition from being an enslaved person to a free individual, C. It was a strategic move to gain more attention as an orator, D. It represented a new chapter in her life as a missionary for God Correct Option: D
Question 6: Analyze the quote from Sojourner Truth's memoir: "Have I not faith enough to go out and quell that mob… I felt as if I had three hearts! And that they were so large, my body could hardly hold them!" What does this passage reveal about Truth's character? Options: A. She was timid and fearful in the face of danger, B. She was confident in her faith and willing to take risks, C. She was primarily motivated by a desire for personal gain, D. She was uncertain about her role as an orator Correct Option: B
Question 7: How did Sojourner Truth's work with the Union Army during the Civil War reflect her broader activism? Options: A. It marked a shift away from her focus on abolition and women's rights, B. It demonstrated her commitment to supporting formerly enslaved people and advocating for their rights, C. It was a strategic move to gain more influence with President Lincoln, D. It was a brief and insignificant part of her life's work Correct Option: B
Question 8: Synthesize the information from the transcript to describe Sojourner Truth's relationship with her faith. How did it shape her life and work? Options: A. Her faith was a source of comfort but did not influence her activism, B. She was skeptical of organized religion and its role in society, C. Her faith was a central part of her life, guiding her decisions and fueling her advocacy for justice and equality, D. She saw faith as a means to an end, using it to manipulate others and achieve her goals Correct Option: C
Question 9: Evaluate the significance of Sojourner Truth's meeting with President Lincoln. What did it reveal about her influence and reputation as an activist? Options: A. It demonstrated her lack of influence and reputation outside of abolitionist circles, B. It showed that she was willing to compromise on her values to gain access to power, C. It highlighted her growing recognition and respect as a prominent advocate for formerly enslaved people, D. It was an isolated incident with little broader significance Correct Option: C
Question 10: What message do you think Sojourner Truth would want readers to take away from her life story, as recorded in the transcript? Options: A. That faith and activism are mutually exclusive, B. That individual actions cannot lead to meaningful change, C. That perseverance, faith, and a commitment to justice can lead to a life of purpose and impact, D. That the abolition of slavery was the only significant issue of her time Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In early 1828, Sojourner Truth approached
the Grand Jury of Kingston, New York. She had no experience 
with the legal system, no money, and no power 
in the eyes of the court. Ignoring the jury’s scorn, Truth said she was there to fight for
custody of her five-year-old son Peter, who’d been illegally sold 
to an enslaver in Alabama. As the trial played out 
over the next several months, Truth raised funds, 
strategized with lawyers, and held her faith. Finally in the spring of 1828, 
Peter was returned to her care— but Truth’s work was far from over. She would dedicate 
the rest of her life to pursuing justice and spiritual understanding. Truth was born into slavery 
as Isabella Baumfree in the late 18th century
in Ulster County, New York. Although New York state had announced 
the abolition of slavery in 1799, the emancipation act was gradual. Those who were currently enslaved were forced to serve a period of 
indentured servitude until their mid-20s. Throughout this period, 
enslavers repeatedly sold Baumfree, tearing her from her loved ones. Often, she was explicitly prevented 
from pursuing new relationships. Eventually, she married an enslaved man 
named Thomas, with whom she had three children. She was desperate to keep 
her new family together— but the slow progress of abolition 
threatened this hope. Baumfree’s enslaver, John Dumont, 
had promised to free her by 1826. When he failed to keep his word, 
Baumfree fled for her safety. During the escape, she was only able 
to rescue her youngest daughter Sophia, while her other children 
remained in bondage. It would be two years before 
she regained custody of Peter. After that, she would wait 
another two years before she saw any of her other children. During this time, 
Baumfree found solace in her faith and became increasingly dedicated 
to religious reflection. After settling in Kingston, New York, she joined a Methodist community 
that shared her political views. She continued her practice of speaking 
aloud to God in private, and one night, her evening prayers
took on even more sacred significance. Baumfree claimed to hear the voice 
of God, telling her to leave Kingston, and share her holy message with others. Though she never learned to read or write, Baumfree became known 
as an electrifying orator, whose speeches drew on 
Biblical references, spiritual ideals, 
and her experience of slavery. Her sermons denounced the oppression 
of African Americans and women in general, and became prominent in campaigns 
for both abolition and women’s rights. In 1843, she renamed herself 
Sojourner Truth and embarked on a legendary 
speaking tour. Truth saw her journey 
as a mission from God. Her faith often led her 
to the nation’s most hostile regions, where she spoke to bigoted audiences 
as the only Black woman in the crowd. Truth was confident God would protect her, but some crowds responded 
to her bravery with violence. During one of her sermons, a mob of white men threatened to set 
fire to the tent where she was speaking. In her memoir, Truth recalled steeling 
herself to confront them: “Have I not faith enough to go out 
and quell that mob… I felt as if I had three hearts! And that they were so large, 
my body could hardly hold them!” She placated the men with song and prayer,
until they had no desire to harm her. Truth’s speeches impacted thousands of
people in communities across the nation, but her activism went far beyond
public speaking. During the Civil War, she became involved
with the Union Army, recruiting soldiers and organizing 
supplies for Black troops. Her work was so well regarded that 
she was invited to meet President Lincoln. She took the occasion to argue 
that all formerly enslaved people should be granted land by the government. Truth continued to travel 
and speak well into her 80s. Until her death in 1883, 
she remained an outspoken critic who fought for her right to be heard 
in a hostile world. As Truth once said, “I feel safe even
in the midst of my enemies; for the truth is powerful 
and will prevail."

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In what state did Sojourner Truth experience slavery?
Options: A. Georgia, B. Massachusetts, C. New York, D. South Carolina
Correct Option: C

He changed his mind about abolition, C. The transcript does not specify a reason, D. He was forced to keep her due to economic reasons Correct Option: C

Character witnesses for Truth's parenting abilities Correct Option: C

They caused her to become disillusioned with the abolition movement, C. They shaped her speeches and sermons, which denounced oppression and advocated for abolition and women's rights, D. It represented a new chapter in her life as a missionary for God Correct Option: D

She was confident in her faith and willing to take risks, C. She was primarily motivated by a desire for personal gain, D. She was uncertain about her role as an orator Correct Option: B

It demonstrated her commitment to supporting formerly enslaved people and advocating for their rights, C. It was a strategic move to gain more influence with President Lincoln, D. It highlighted her growing recognition and respect as a prominent advocate for formerly enslaved people, D. It was an isolated incident with little broader significance Correct Option: C

That faith and activism are mutually exclusive, B. That individual actions cannot lead to meaningful change, C. That perseverance, faith, and a commitment to justice can lead to a life of purpose and impact, D. That the abolition of slavery was the only significant issue of her time Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In early 1828, Sojourner Truth approached
the Grand Jury of Kingston, New York. She had no experience 
with the legal system, no money, and no power 
in the eyes of the court. Ignoring the jury’s scorn, Truth said she was there to fight for
custody of her five-year-old son Peter, who’d been illegally sold 
to an enslaver in Alabama. As the trial played out 
over the next several months, Truth raised funds, 
strategized with lawyers, and held her faith. Finally in the spring of 1828, 
Peter was returned to her care— but Truth’s work was far from over. She would dedicate 
the rest of her life to pursuing justice and spiritual understanding. Truth was born into slavery 
as Isabella Baumfree in the late 18th century
in Ulster County, New York. Although New York state had announced 
the abolition of slavery in 1799, the emancipation act was gradual. Those who were currently enslaved were forced to serve a period of 
indentured servitude until their mid-20s. Throughout this period, 
enslavers repeatedly sold Baumfree, tearing her from her loved ones. Often, she was explicitly prevented 
from pursuing new relationships. Eventually, she married an enslaved man 
named Thomas, with whom she had three children. She was desperate to keep 
her new family together— but the slow progress of abolition 
threatened this hope. Baumfree’s enslaver, John Dumont, 
had promised to free her by 1826. When he failed to keep his word, 
Baumfree fled for her safety. During the escape, she was only able 
to rescue her youngest daughter Sophia, while her other children 
remained in bondage. It would be two years before 
she regained custody of Peter. After that, she would wait 
another two years before she saw any of her other children. During this time, 
Baumfree found solace in her faith and became increasingly dedicated 
to religious reflection. After settling in Kingston, New York, she joined a Methodist community 
that shared her political views. She continued her practice of speaking 
aloud to God in private, and one night, her evening prayers
took on even more sacred significance. Baumfree claimed to hear the voice 
of God, telling her to leave Kingston, and share her holy message with others. Though she never learned to read or write, Baumfree became known 
as an electrifying orator, whose speeches drew on 
Biblical references, spiritual ideals, 
and her experience of slavery. Her sermons denounced the oppression 
of African Americans and women in general, and became prominent in campaigns 
for both abolition and women’s rights. In 1843, she renamed herself 
Sojourner Truth and embarked on a legendary 
speaking tour. Truth saw her journey 
as a mission from God. Her faith often led her 
to the nation’s most hostile regions, where she spoke to bigoted audiences 
as the only Black woman in the crowd. Truth was confident God would protect her, but some crowds responded 
to her bravery with violence. During one of her sermons, a mob of white men threatened to set 
fire to the tent where she was speaking. In her memoir, Truth recalled steeling 
herself to confront them: “Have I not faith enough to go out 
and quell that mob… I felt as if I had three hearts! And that they were so large, 
my body could hardly hold them!” She placated the men with song and prayer,
until they had no desire to harm her. Truth’s speeches impacted thousands of
people in communities across the nation, but her activism went far beyond
public speaking. During the Civil War, she became involved
with the Union Army, recruiting soldiers and organizing 
supplies for Black troops. Her work was so well regarded that 
she was invited to meet President Lincoln. She took the occasion to argue 
that all formerly enslaved people should be granted land by the government. Truth continued to travel 
and speak well into her 80s. Until her death in 1883, 
she remained an outspoken critic who fought for her right to be heard 
in a hostile world. As Truth once said, “I feel safe even
in the midst of my enemies; for the truth is powerful 
and will prevail."

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Many people know of Truth for her activism, but she was also a wife and mother of how many children?
Options: A. 2, B. 3, C. 4, D. 5
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. **Transcript**:
In early 1828, Sojourner Truth approached
the Grand Jury of Kingston, New York. She had no experience 
with the legal system, no money, and no power 
in the eyes of the court. Ignoring the jury’s scorn, Truth said she was there to fight for
custody of her five-year-old son Peter, who’d been illegally sold 
to an enslaver in Alabama. As the trial played out 
over the next several months, Truth raised funds, 
strategized with lawyers, and held her faith. Finally in the spring of 1828, 
Peter was returned to her care— but Truth’s work was far from over. She would dedicate 
the rest of her life to pursuing justice and spiritual understanding. Truth was born into slavery 
as Isabella Baumfree in the late 18th century
in Ulster County, New York. Although New York state had announced 
the abolition of slavery in 1799, the emancipation act was gradual. Those who were currently enslaved were forced to serve a period of 
indentured servitude until their mid-20s. Throughout this period, 
enslavers repeatedly sold Baumfree, tearing her from her loved ones. Often, she was explicitly prevented 
from pursuing new relationships. Eventually, she married an enslaved man 
named Thomas, with whom she had three children. She was desperate to keep 
her new family together— but the slow progress of abolition 
threatened this hope. Baumfree’s enslaver, John Dumont, 
had promised to free her by 1826. When he failed to keep his word, 
Baumfree fled for her safety. During the escape, she was only able 
to rescue her youngest daughter Sophia, while her other children 
remained in bondage. It would be two years before 
she regained custody of Peter. After that, she would wait 
another two years before she saw any of her other children. During this time, 
Baumfree found solace in her faith and became increasingly dedicated 
to religious reflection. After settling in Kingston, New York, she joined a Methodist community 
that shared her political views. She continued her practice of speaking 
aloud to God in private, and one night, her evening prayers
took on even more sacred significance. Baumfree claimed to hear the voice 
of God, telling her to leave Kingston, and share her holy message with others. Though she never learned to read or write, Baumfree became known 
as an electrifying orator, whose speeches drew on 
Biblical references, spiritual ideals, 
and her experience of slavery. Her sermons denounced the oppression 
of African Americans and women in general, and became prominent in campaigns 
for both abolition and women’s rights. In 1843, she renamed herself 
Sojourner Truth and embarked on a legendary 
speaking tour. Truth saw her journey 
as a mission from God. Her faith often led her 
to the nation’s most hostile regions, where she spoke to bigoted audiences 
as the only Black woman in the crowd. Truth was confident God would protect her, but some crowds responded 
to her bravery with violence. During one of her sermons, a mob of white men threatened to set 
fire to the tent where she was speaking. In her memoir, Truth recalled steeling 
herself to confront them: “Have I not faith enough to go out 
and quell that mob… I felt as if I had three hearts! And that they were so large, 
my body could hardly hold them!” She placated the men with song and prayer,
until they had no desire to harm her. Truth’s speeches impacted thousands of
people in communities across the nation, but her activism went far beyond
public speaking. During the Civil War, she became involved
with the Union Army, recruiting soldiers and organizing 
supplies for Black troops. Her work was so well regarded that 
she was invited to meet President Lincoln. She took the occasion to argue 
that all formerly enslaved people should be granted land by the government. Truth continued to travel 
and speak well into her 80s. Until her death in 1883, 
she remained an outspoken critic who fought for her right to be heard 
in a hostile world. As Truth once said, “I feel safe even
in the midst of my enemies; for the truth is powerful 
and will prevail."

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to the lesson, what were the main causes Truth supported?

Correct Option: A

Character witnesses for Truth's parenting abilities Correct Option: C
Question 4: How did Sojourner Truth's experiences with slavery and abolition influence her later work as an orator and activist? Options: A. They led her to focus solely on women's rights, B. They caused her to become disillusioned with the abolition movement, C. They shaped her speeches and sermons, which denounced oppression and advocated for abolition and women's rights, D. They had no impact on her later work Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the significance of Sojourner Truth's decision to rename herself in 1843? Options: A. It marked her conversion to a new religion, B. It signaled her transition from being an enslaved person to a free individual, C. It was a strategic move to gain more attention as an orator, D. It represented a new chapter in her life as a missionary for God Correct Option: D
Question 6: Analyze the quote from Sojourner Truth's memoir: "Have I not faith enough to go out and quell that mob… I felt as if I had three hearts! And that they were so large, my body could hardly hold them!" What does this passage reveal about Truth's character? Options: A. She was timid and fearful in the face of danger, B. She was confident in her faith and willing to take risks, C. She was primarily motivated by a desire for personal gain, D. She was uncertain about her role as an orator Correct Option: B
Question 7: How did Sojourner Truth's work with the Union Army during the Civil War reflect her broader activism? Options: A. It marked a shift away from her focus on abolition and women's rights, B. It demonstrated her commitment to supporting formerly enslaved people and advocating for their rights, C. It was a strategic move to gain more influence with President Lincoln, D. It was a brief and insignificant part of her life's work Correct Option: B
Question 8: Synthesize the information from the transcript to describe Sojourner Truth's relationship with her faith. How did it shape her life and work? Options: A. Her faith was a source of comfort but did not influence her activism, B. She was skeptical of organized religion and its role in society, C. Her faith was a central part of her life, guiding her decisions and fueling her advocacy for justice and equality, D. She saw faith as a means to an end, using it to manipulate others and achieve her goals Correct Option: C
Question 9: Evaluate the significance of Sojourner Truth's meeting with President Lincoln. What did it reveal about her influence and reputation as an activist? Options: A. It demonstrated her lack of influence and reputation outside of abolitionist circles, B. It showed that she was willing to compromise on her values to gain access to power, C. It highlighted her growing recognition and respect as a prominent advocate for formerly enslaved people, D. It was an isolated incident with little broader significance Correct Option: C
Question 10: What message do you think Sojourner Truth would want readers to take away from her life story, as recorded in the transcript? Options: A. That faith and activism are mutually exclusive, B. That individual actions cannot lead to meaningful change, C. That perseverance, faith, and a commitment to justice can lead to a life of purpose and impact, D. That the abolition of slavery was the only significant issue of her time Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In early 1828, Sojourner Truth approached
the Grand Jury of Kingston, New York. She had no experience 
with the legal system, no money, and no power 
in the eyes of the court. Ignoring the jury’s scorn, Truth said she was there to fight for
custody of her five-year-old son Peter, who’d been illegally sold 
to an enslaver in Alabama. As the trial played out 
over the next several months, Truth raised funds, 
strategized with lawyers, and held her faith. Finally in the spring of 1828, 
Peter was returned to her care— but Truth’s work was far from over. She would dedicate 
the rest of her life to pursuing justice and spiritual understanding. Truth was born into slavery 
as Isabella Baumfree in the late 18th century
in Ulster County, New York. Although New York state had announced 
the abolition of slavery in 1799, the emancipation act was gradual. Those who were currently enslaved were forced to serve a period of 
indentured servitude until their mid-20s. Throughout this period, 
enslavers repeatedly sold Baumfree, tearing her from her loved ones. Often, she was explicitly prevented 
from pursuing new relationships. Eventually, she married an enslaved man 
named Thomas, with whom she had three children. She was desperate to keep 
her new family together— but the slow progress of abolition 
threatened this hope. Baumfree’s enslaver, John Dumont, 
had promised to free her by 1826. When he failed to keep his word, 
Baumfree fled for her safety. During the escape, she was only able 
to rescue her youngest daughter Sophia, while her other children 
remained in bondage. It would be two years before 
she regained custody of Peter. After that, she would wait 
another two years before she saw any of her other children. During this time, 
Baumfree found solace in her faith and became increasingly dedicated 
to religious reflection. After settling in Kingston, New York, she joined a Methodist community 
that shared her political views. She continued her practice of speaking 
aloud to God in private, and one night, her evening prayers
took on even more sacred significance. Baumfree claimed to hear the voice 
of God, telling her to leave Kingston, and share her holy message with others. Though she never learned to read or write, Baumfree became known 
as an electrifying orator, whose speeches drew on 
Biblical references, spiritual ideals, 
and her experience of slavery. Her sermons denounced the oppression 
of African Americans and women in general, and became prominent in campaigns 
for both abolition and women’s rights. In 1843, she renamed herself 
Sojourner Truth and embarked on a legendary 
speaking tour. Truth saw her journey 
as a mission from God. Her faith often led her 
to the nation’s most hostile regions, where she spoke to bigoted audiences 
as the only Black woman in the crowd. Truth was confident God would protect her, but some crowds responded 
to her bravery with violence. During one of her sermons, a mob of white men threatened to set 
fire to the tent where she was speaking. In her memoir, Truth recalled steeling 
herself to confront them: “Have I not faith enough to go out 
and quell that mob… I felt as if I had three hearts! And that they were so large, 
my body could hardly hold them!” She placated the men with song and prayer,
until they had no desire to harm her. Truth’s speeches impacted thousands of
people in communities across the nation, but her activism went far beyond
public speaking. During the Civil War, she became involved
with the Union Army, recruiting soldiers and organizing 
supplies for Black troops. Her work was so well regarded that 
she was invited to meet President Lincoln. She took the occasion to argue 
that all formerly enslaved people should be granted land by the government. Truth continued to travel 
and speak well into her 80s. Until her death in 1883, 
she remained an outspoken critic who fought for her right to be heard 
in a hostile world. As Truth once said, “I feel safe even
in the midst of my enemies; for the truth is powerful 
and will prevail."

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was Truth’s role in the Civil War?
Options: A. Fighting on the front lines, B. Nursing wounded soldiers, C. Advocating for and recruiting Black soldiers, D. Cleaning weapons and artillery
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 1

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. [Music] [Applause] well this is a really extraordinary honor for me I spend most of my time in jails in prisons on death row I spend most of my time in very low-income communities and the projects and places where there's a great deal of hopelessness and being here at Ted and and seeing the stimulation hearing it has been very very energizing to me and one of the things that's emerged in my short time here is that Ted has an identity and you can actually say things here that have impacts around the world and sometimes when it comes through Ted it has meaning and power that it doesn't have when it doesn't and I mention that because I think identity is really important and we've had some fantastic presentations and I think what we've learned is that if you're a teacher your words can be meaningful but if you're a compassionate teacher they can be especially meaningful if you're a doctor you can do some good things but if you're a caring doctor you can do some other things so I want to talk about the power of identity and I didn't learn about this actually practicing law and doing the work that I do I I I actually learned about this from my grandmother I grew up in a house uh that was the traditional African-American home that was dominated by a matriarch and that matriarch was my grandmother that she was tough she was strong she was powerful uh she was the end of every argument in our family uh she was the beginning of a lot of arguments in our family uh she was the daughter of people who were actually enslaved her parents were born ens slavery in Virginia in the 1840s she was born in the 1880s and the experience of slavery very much shaped the way she saw the world and my mother my grandmother was tough but she was also loving when I would see her as a little boy she'd come up to me and she'd give me these hugs and she'd squeeze me so tight I could barely breathe and then she'd let me go and an hour or two later if I saw her she'd come over to me and she'd say Brian do you still feel me hugging you and if I said no she'd assault me again and if I'd say yes she'd leave me alone and then she just had this quality that you always wanted to be near her and the only challenge was that she had 10 children my mom was the youngest of her 10 kids and sometimes when I would go and spend time with her it'd be difficult to get her time and attention my cousins would be running around everywhere and I remember uh when I was about 8 or 9 years old waking up one morning going into the living room and all of my cousins were running around and my grandmother was sitting across the room staring at me and at first I thought we were playing a game and I would look at her and I'd smile but she was very serious and after about 15 or 20 minutes of this she got up and she came across the room and she took me by the hand and she said come on Brian you and I going to have a talk and I remember this just like it happened yesterday and never will forget it she she
